text:
I’ve had trouble with remote ssh julia paths before. I edited the main remote settings.json to include environment paths and executable path. The main settings.json can be a bit tricky to find. I believe it should be in ~/.vscode-server/data/Machine. If not, through vs code, head to remote ssh settings, toggle to remote machine settings and find ‘Remote: Extension kind’, underwhich there should be an option to edit the remote settings.json.

Presumably it’s finding your old environment and setting that as the default environment. I think you can change this in the remote settings.json. You can also change for a particular directory by editing the /directory/.vscode/settings.json and including the desired environment path.

I’m not sure why the cpu bursts. I remember having his when the language server was indexing on start up.

attachments.text: I think there are some VS Code settings that one can use to add things to env vars. Here is one theory: you have that configured to add /julia-1.3.1/bin to your PATH. Your bash profiles are adding Julia 1.4 to the PATH. When you start a plain terminal in VS Code, you therefor end up with both in the PATH.
